Yen-based trades account for high proportion of Bitcoin market
Price movements for the cryptocurrency Bitcoin have been attracting attention. The price rose exponentially in the second half of 2017, hitting a record high of $19,497 on 16 December. This is a remarkable increase over the 1 January 2017 price of $998. Although the price dropped sharply to less than $12,000 after that for a time, it then rebounded to approach $16,100 as of 26 December. Looking at the Bitcoin market trading volume by currency shows that around 40% of trades are on a yen basis. This is bigger than the US dollar share, and suggests that individual investors in Japan are a major presence on the market.

PM11:05am

Wealth effect from rapid rise in Bitcoin prices
As of 25 December, the market cap of Bitcoin traded in yen had increased to roughly ¥5.1trn on an Oct-Dec average basis. Assuming that much of this ¥5.1trn belongs to Japanese investors, this represents a substantial increase in asset value.
Generally speaking, rises in asset values often result in a rise in consumer spending too, known as the wealth effect. In this report, we estimate the wealth effect from unrealized gains on Bitcoin trading by Japanese investors since the start of FY17, and estimate a potential boost to consumer spending of ¥23.2-96.0bn (see the main text for our calculation method). Moreover, the fact that the rise in Bitcoin prices was concentrated in 2017 Q4 could result in the wealth effect materializing in 2018 Q1, and if that is the case, we estimate a potential boost to real GDP growth on an annualized q-q basis of up to about 0.3ppt (¥96.0bn / ¥130trn × 4).
To what extent major Bitcoin owners who have increased their assets through the end of the year will bolster consumer spending through the beginning of year remains to be seen, but we should keep in mind the possibility that spending will exceed expectations as a result of this factor.

Tom Dalgleish Happy 2018 in this year of the dog
11:05 am
PM11:06am

Let me add a bit more detail

PM11:06am

Given that Japan's real GDP is around ¥522trn (2016 calendar year-basis), the y-y boost to GDP from this spending per se works out at just 0.07ppt. That said, given that the sharp rise in the price of Bitcoin occurred mainly in 2017 Q4, if that same wealth effect is replicated in 2018 Q1, we estimate it would boost annualized q-q real GDP growth by around 0.3ppt (= ¥96.0bn / quarterly GDP of ¥130trn x 4), which on a quarterly basis represents an impact on a scale that cannot be ignored

PM11:06am

And...

11:06 am
PM11:06am

One point that does need to be kept in mind is the difference between the wealth effect impact resulting from an increase in asset value caused by a rise in the price of Bitcoin, and an increase in asset value resulting from share price gains. Particularly in the case of Bitcoin, the high level of price volatility means that the formation of expectations vis-a- vis future asset value will doubtless be unstable compared with share prices and other financial assets on which the earlier studies were based. In Figure 5 we have therefore shown the discounted wealth effect of Bitcoin transactions based on the volatility of both Nikkei 225 share prices and the price of Bitcoin.
To what extent major Bitcoin holders who have increased their assets through the end of the year will bolster consumer spending through the beginning of year remains to be seen, but we should keep in mind the possibility that spending will exceed expectations as a result of this factor

Summary: Despite edging lower from November’s high, manufacturing PMIs remain on a solid footing, supported by the intermediate and investment sectors, while the consumer goods sectors remain in the doldrums. December easing was broad based, but new orders dropped the most and employment cooled to its lowest reading in six months. Price indicators eased somewhat but remain elevated. The gap between UK and EA manufacturing momentum has widened in December.

BE11:16am

· Manufacturing PMIs eased back from multi-year highs reached in November. The downwards correction was broad based, with all the sub indexes edging lower, but the drop in new orders (-4.3 points) stands out. Also, the employment gauge fell back by 2.3 points and is now just 0.7SD above its long-term average, driven by consumer goods, where the employment index fell back on its 50 point mark, the lowest in nine months. But on the other side, export orders helped keep levels of backlog of work high, ensuring production for the months ahead. Also, on a quarterly basis, the manufacturing sector delivered its strongest performance since mid-2014, suggesting another positive contribution to Q4 GDP growth and carrying over a strong momentum into 2018.

· Inflationary pressures eased but remained elevated overall. Companies reported “rising raw material prices, input shortage, suppliers raising their prices and the exchange rates” as ongoing reasons behind price pressures. With overall demand still strong, producers felt confident to pass on some of these price increases to their clients. With demand the weakest in the consumer goods sectors, price pressures there eased the most, while in the investment goods sectors, the output price index remained largely unchanged.

· The December reading continues to point to manufacturing strength but also comes with mixed blessings. Despite elevated levels of production on orders, producers continue to hold back expanding capacity and now also seem to be reducing their hiring plans. Also, strength in intermediate and investment goods is overshadowed by weakness in the consumer sector, where most of the indices are at or below their long-term average. Going into 2018, we like the overall momentum as highlighted by a strong quarterly reading, but we do not feel overly confident regarding the sustainability of the manufacturing recovery. As long as global growth powers ahead, the UK manufacturing sector will be dragged along, but data point to a continued loss of market share as the economy increasingly feels the pinch of business uncertainty and capacity constraints. Particularly telling is the growing gap between manufacturing momentum in the UK and the EA.

BE11:17am

This is a little disappointing for the UK at the end of 2017. Globally, the PMIs have tended to point
to a strong end to the year: the Eurozone, China and India all saw rises in December. However, it is
hardly a bad reading: at 56.3 the manufacturing PMI stands well above its long-term average of
51.5, its post-referendum low of 48.5 and its 2017 average of 55.9. All in all, the manufacturing
sector has been a bit stronger of late - though industrial production overall is likely to look weak in
Q4 due to the outages at the Forties oil pipeline in December. The key question as usual is the
services PMI: the index of services, which accounts for 80% of UK GDP, was a little stronger than
expected in October, but the PMI survey dropped back in November. The December reading (due
on 4 January) will shed a little further light ahead of the preliminary GDP growth reading for Q4
on 26 January. Our forecast is for a slowdown to 0.3% q-o-q (from 0.4% in Q3), though the strong
October services print suggests risks could be to the upside.

Generally, though, things remain tough, The main pick from all this is turning to buy on Asos.

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 6,800, up 85 (+1.27%), High: 6,840, Low: 6,734, Volume: 96.78k
BE11:22am

ASOS is well placed to continue to benefit from the online channel shift, underpinned by a high pace of active customer number additions, as well as expansion into the activewear and beauty categories. In particular in 2018 we expect strong growth in Europe, as the company delivers the full service and cost benefits of its localised logistics and digital shopfronts. Meanwhile, customer economics remain very strong with payback on acquisition costs more than twice as fast as at Zalando. We modestly increase our long-term revenue and margin forecasts and our target price increases to 7,400p. This implies the shares de-rate in 2018 from 2.0x to 1.8x 12-month forward EV/sales, versus a long-run average of 2.1x.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

And here are your five reasons to buy.

BE11:23am

[1] that the growth of clothing retail online continues unabated in ASOS' key markets, [2] that ASOS itself remains well positioned to gain share of this channel, including still in its home market of UK which is now less than 40% of group, [3] range expansion into face & body (since September) and own-label activewear (later this month) expands the total addressable market, and most importantly the addressable wallet of each of its customers, [4] international expansion, especially near term in continental Europe, has strong prospects as the company benefits from its new Eurohub facility. In 2019 a new US site should drive a similar step-change in customer service and lower cost-to-serve levels. And [5] customer economics remain strong with a payback in new acquisitions of just one year, substantially stronger than peers such as Sell-rated Zalando (current price E44.24).

BE11:27am

The top-down macro indicators imply that consumers have likely spentcautiously this Christmas. Nevertheless, we expect strong online and multichannel retailers and the discounters to emerge as winners over the 2017 festive period. We maintain our cautious stance into the early stages of 2018 and across our UK coverage we would own B&M, boohoo, M&S, Kingfisher and Ted Baker.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We believe consumers have likely spent cautiously when celebrating over the 2017 festive period. That's because consumer confidence has been weak in the second half of 2017 averaging -11pts (vs -5pts Jan-May) and December saw consumer confidence fall again to -13pts (6pts lower than December 2016). In addition, inflation of c.3% has eroded consumer spending power as household disposable income fell by £1 p/w yoy (or c.-1%) to £199 per week per household in November (ASDA). On the upside, the weather has been more seasonal in November/December (after a warm October) and the unemployment rate is very low. However, given the wider macro backdrop we take a cautious stance.

BE11:30am

2018 could be another tough year, as we expect the trends of the macro indicators
mentioned above to persist (at least in the near term). Inflation is expected to ease into
the second half of 2018, which should provide some relief. However, with real GDP growth
expected to slow, ongoing Brexit negotiations and rising interest rates we think consumers
will spend prudently in 2018. In light of this, in the UK we have a preference for discounters
like B&M who are well positioned for any weakness in the consumer environment (see
"Growth In A Tough Market"), strong online retailers like boohoo (see "Feel the Buzz"),
retailers with compelling self-help stories like M&S (see "M&S Food: Worth A Bite") and
Kingfisher (see "From Disruption to Redemption. Upgrade to Buy") or retailers with strong
brand equity like Ted Baker (see "Steady As She Grows"). We would avoid cyclically leveraged
retailers like Dunelm (see "Ambition vs Competition") or operationally challenged retailers
like Sports Direct (see "SPDexit. Downgrade to Underperform").

11:36 am

BE11:37am

Wee bit of comment from RBC.

BE11:37am

As we have previously said (Buy or be bought – 5/9/17), we think the group would be attractive to the private market although the recent warning has muddied the picture somewhat. Key is Mark Dixon, who still owns 25% - he last sold at 345p – Our view is that he is unlikely sell at this price, but we wouldn’t rule out him rolling his stake into the private market, allowing him to grow the business without worrying about short-term EPS.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

And Peel Hunt, from last year.

BE11:38am

The approach is from private equity at the moment, but we see potential bidders from a range of parties, including global real estate developers, or those with a global ambition, to other industry players – although private equity is much the most likely in our view. IWG is a global brand with established positions in every significant country, where it has created local teams many of which are at an early stage of scale economies, working to proven business templates across the full range of lease/management offer, supported by a cost effective back office. It is highly cash generative and minimally financially geared (although highly operationally geared) given that leases remain off balance sheet. On many metrics it is good value.

BE11:38am

Any bid will have to take account of more factors than a simple DCF of what the business is worth (our own DCF gives huge spreads in value depending on how many years of growth are factored in, to name but one variable). A nonexhaustive list includes: a judgement call on the impact of competition; the current low expectations of investors; vulnerabilities in its most profitable markets such as London; deliverability of forecasts; management factors including Mark Dixon and his desire to remain involved (noting his recent share sales); long-term growth opportunities; the benefit of being private rather than public (growth could be accelerated).

11:39 am
BE11:39am

On valuation ......

BE11:39am

 The PER at today’s 250p of 16.6x FY18E and 14.5x FY19E is low for a global leader, and low by IWG’s own historical levels, especially when the dilutive effect of expansion is considered.

 High FCF yield (pre growth capex) of 12.0% for FY18E and 14.2% for FY19E is attractive.

 We see above 300p as achievable in a competitive bid situation, butacknowledge the uncertainties attached. 260-270p as a trading price seems appropriate for now

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Small bolt-on acquisition but low cost DNA continues to build: (i) Potential to top up IAG EBIT by 1%: NIKI held a c6% share in Palma and Dusseldorf with 1-3% at Vienna, Hamburg and Munich in 3Q17, with a firm focus on Spanish/Mediterranean holiday destinations. Achieving comparable profitability to Vueling from NIKI planes may suggest a c€25m EBIT opportunity (1% of our 2018E IAG EBIT). (ii) Efficiency advantage over Eurowings: The move puts Vueling more into competition with Lufthansa’s Eurowings, and we highlight a 2017E Vueling ex-fuel/staff/airports CASK c25% lower than EW, suggesting opportunity. (iii) Second derivative effects key to long term returns at BA/IAG: IAG continues to expand the proportion of seats operated by low cost platforms within the group, which we continue to see as helpful to BA’s efforts to modernise its cost base (each 1% move in BA employee costs is worth c1% to group EBIT). We also see expansion outside of IAG’s UK/Spain core as strategically important as it looks to develop long haul low cost carrier LEVEL; LEVEL recently announced a Paris base to supplement its maiden Barcelona base and we expect IAG to continue to develop LEVEL’s pan-European footprint

expect Phase III data for EU development of Favolir, a nebulised steroid for
severe asthma, proprietary to Vectura. We see very little value ascribed to this
program by the market, in part due to the lack of a partner. A partnering
announcement following positive Phase III data could see increased appreciation. In
our view the Phase III has a good chance of reporting positive data, with a very
similar design to the Phase II, which reported stronger efficacy than conventional
nebulisers. We model $250m peak potential, which could be worth 20p per share,
assuming a 20% royalty arrangement. (2.) We also expect an update on US
generic Advair in Q1’18. Our base case is no approval until late 2019, as we expect
further clinical data will now be required. We see very little in the current share price
for this program, and hence see limited downside under our base-case scenario, with
wild-card upside, should the FDA be convinced to approve on the existing data.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

2018 should also see solid operating performance. We forecast recurring Revenues
to grow 10%, Group Revenues up 9%. We forecast EBITDA down 6%, with
negative mix from higher Flutiform supply sales with associated manufacturing
costs. We don’t anticipate a US tax reform benefit, with the company already paying
a low patent box based tax rate, on royalty income.
Our risk-adjusted NPV derived PT of 170p implies 65% potential upside, the
highest in our 24 stock Pharma & Biotech coverage universe, with shares
trading in line with our ex-pipeline base business valuation. Hence, although
some patience may be required to see the valuation gap narrowed, we remain
Overweight.
